justification: The paper states, "We review four common measures of algorithmic fairness: (i) statistical parity, (ii) conditional statistical parity, (iii) separation, and (iv) sufficiency."
In the same review section the authors list "conditional statistical parity" as one of the four common measures of algorithmic fairness.
Separation is introduced as the third of the "four common measures of algorithmic fairness," defined formally in Equation 3.
The authors name "sufficiency" as the fourth common measure, noting, "Sufficiency requires that the outcome be independent of the group conditional on the algorithmic decision."
The introduction notes that "Psychometricians have developed DIF frameworks and relevant methods to measure the fairness and validity of tests at the item level."
Among "common methods to detect the presence of DIF" the article lists "the Mantel-Haenszel test (Shealy & Stout, 1993)."
The same list of DIF methods includes "logistic regression (Swaminathan & Rogers, 1990)" for detecting DIF.
The paper cites "item-response-theory-based methods, e.g., area measures (Kim & Cohen, 1991; Raju, 1988)" as tools for measuring DIF.
Residual-based DIF is mentioned as a modern method: "and residual-based DIF (Lim et al., 2022)."
The authors explain, "we adopt the aforementioned methods for DIF: the Mantel-Haenszel test… to detect the presence of DAF in algorithms."
Equation 10 shows a logistic regression model and the text states, "The logistic regression procedure requires fitting the following model… We can detect the presence of DAF…"
The manuscript introduces "a residual-based DAF method" that computes three statistics (RDAF_R, RDAF_S, RDAF_RS) "designed to detect different types of DAF."
